header.title: Why are women paid less than men? | The Economist
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: The gender pay gap is not caused by women earning less than men for the same job. It is largely because women choose different careers and suffer a 'motherhood penalty''.. . Click here to subscribe to The Economist on YouTube: http://econ.st/2Bnu9E9 . . Women who work full-time, still earn 15% less than men. But that's not because they are paid less for the same jobs. It's because they're in different jobs.. . Women are in less senior jobs. In Britain, France and Germany, 80-90% of executive jobs are held by men.  Women also tend to choose different occupations.. . In America over 80% of teachers, nurses, secretaries, and health workers are female and these jobs tend to be lower paid. Primary school teachers in the West earn nearly 20% less than the average graduate job. . . Nurses earn less than police officers. Cleaners less than caretakers. . . Women are as ambitious as men. They earn the majority of university degrees. In America, they now ask for promotions as often as men.. . But it's the price women pay for motherhood that holds them back. In Britain, 70% of mothers reduced their working hours or switched to a less demanding job compared with 11% of fathers.. . In Australia it's 56% of mothers and 19% of fathers, while in France 55% of mothers scaled back compared to 13% of fathers.. . When an American women goes back to work her salary is on average lower than it would have been if she hadn't had a child. . . The race for gender equality is far from over. As more children choose non-traditional careers and men do more childcare, fewer working women will be held back.. . Daily Watch: mind-stretching short films throughout the working week.. . For more from Economist Films visit: http://econ.st/2Bq9Q9n . Check out The Economist's full video catalogue: http://econ.st/20IehQk . Like The Economist on Facebook: http://econ.st/2Bqvr16 . This is good for everyone, and in fact, because many of my employees wind-up working another job, I don't have to pay all the benefits and related overhead. Again, what's good for me as the employer in terms of lower cost women means I can take advantage of more women employees. In my industry women generally do not push for as much time off, or a raise nearly as often. In fact, I had to fir several men over the past few years who wanted raises when they were already getting 15-25% more than my girls. Also, the women wind up learning more skills by working a second or other jobs, and as such, I find that they have more breadth and depth of experience than the men. So note to other women— SHUT UP, before you ruin it for all of us by trying to get equal wages.

When I applied for a management position at the company I work for, the bosses doing the hiring asked my fellow coworkers which of 'us' they would prefer to get the management position. By 'us', I mean, they asked about all the male applicants and none of the female applicants. None of my coworkers were even aware that I had actually applied. I had told them, but they had assumed that I meant I was planning to apply, but never did, as my name was not listed as an applicant. Afterwards, I spoke to my coworker who had been given the management position. He was shocked that my hourly pay was less than the state's max threshold for overtime pay. Even though he had 2 years less experience in the job, he had been paid above that threshold. After 5 raises, I am still making $1.75 per hour less than that threshold. This is against labor laws that are meant to guarantee pay parity for men and women working the same job with the same experience. There is a loophole to that law, though, as proof of violating the law needs to be shown on the company's pay records, and the company chose to 'not keep any records of that sort of information'. There is a pay gap, and it's not that women simply choose to be paid less. It's that many company's in the US have chosen to not record key pay information, the legal system relies on letting companies self-regulate and self-report violations of labor law (like allowing a child to rat themselves out if they have their hand in the cookie jar - kids aren't going to get themselves in trouble by ratting themselves out and neither are companies), and chalking it all up to women having babies or being overly emotional or just plain lying, even though that's not the case. I really do miss the military's payscale. Paygrade (basically, rank), time in service (basically, experience), allowances (annual set pay for purchasing new uniforms), and special pay (hazard pay for deployment to combat zones, etc.) were factored in; gender was not. Women with the same rank, time in service, and who were in the same situation (both located in a combat zone or both assigned to the same duty station, etc.) were paid the same amount that men were. It's not hard to set up a system like that civilian-side, but until it becomes mandatory for companies to track and report pay records or it becomes possible to admit worker's pay stubs as evidence of pay disparity when any group reports a company for labor law violations. As far as the MGTOW/men's rights denial that the pay gap exists when women demand fair and equal pay for equal work in the same job with the same experience, I find it odd that so many of them are upset about women in porn getting paid more than men. Honestly, using a pay system like the military pay system would fix that, too, yet the MGTOWs, men's rights advocates, top company executives, and shareholders who fight against admitting a pay gap exists in any other job have been against implementing any such system.

Disagree with economist. The gender pay gap is not caused because women choose different careers, it is about how we value these carreers. When female workers begin to dominate a profession, modern day western societies tend to devalue these profession. For instance when women took over nursing in the second half of the 20st century, salaries dropped drastically in comparison to the time when it was male-dominated. This happens with nearly all professions dominated by women, look at the cuts in payment for teachers(dominated by women). Opponents to feminism argue that it is women who choose other jobs, but it is society who devalues the work hard-working women do

commentThread.commentText: There is a number of inaccuracies in this video, although it is not as terrible as I initially expected upon clicking on it. The notion that "women are as ambitious as men" is factually incorrect; in psychology, we know this not to be true. The claim that, as more men choose differing career paths and focus more on paternity, more women will reach executive positions at companies is wrong, or at least has no evidence supporting it. The amount of executive roles at companies is relatively small and unlikely to be affected by a slight increase in variation of male occupations or time off from work. Further, men are never going to take as much time off from work as women do on average. We know that people who get into executive positions have certain temperamental and cognitive advantages that make their selection to these positions more likely, and these properties are, on average, more prevalent among men. Finally, the notion that women are being "held back" by the current societal structure is an unfounded claim. Also, the perverse notion that increased competition is somehow discriminating against women due to unequal outcomes is one that only a mentally-challenged person would think stands to reason. Our biological reality is such that, on average, men are more suited for competitive, high-stress environments, which explains their overall higher wages and more senior roles in society. However, one must not ignore the significant in-group variance within men and women, which is greater than the variance between said groups. In other words, any individual woman can do anything she wants in life, including not having children and thus progressing further in her career, and making a ton of money. What you cannot do however, is a) choose to have a child in the middle of your career, and expect to be still as likely as the average person to get into a senior position, and b) claim that unequal outcomes in life on aggregate are somehow indicative of systematic discrimination against a given group of people.
